keyTakeAways: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American boy, is detained in Israeli jails and is suffering from poor living conditions, including cold cells, inadequate food, and lack of medical care.
He has lost considerable weight since his detention began in February 2025 and has been denied dinner and fruit, with meals described as extremely insufficient.
The case has become a symbol of systemic mistreatment of minors in Israeli military detention facilities, which are criticized for lacking basic human rights protections.
Despite being a US citizen, Mohammed has no protection from US authorities, and his family and rights groups are urging the Trump administration to use diplomatic leverage to secure his release.
Israel is the only country in the world that systematically prosecutes children in military courts, a fact highlighted by Defense for Children International – Palestine (DCIP).
The case gained renewed attention following the Gaza ceasefire deal, which led to the release of Palestinian detainees and intensified calls for Mohammed’s release.
The broader context includes at least 79 Palestinian detainees who have died in Israeli jails since October 2023 due to lack of medical care and abuse, raising international human rights concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American teenager, has been detained in Israeli prisons since February 2025 after being taken into custody during a raid on his family's home in the occupied West Bank. He describes severe conditions including cold cells, minimal meals (such as just three pieces of bread and a spoonful of labneh for breakfast), lack of heating or cooling, and no dinner or fruit. He has lost significant weight and has been charged with throwing stones at Israeli settlers, a charge he denies. The case has drawn international attention from human rights groups like Defense for Children International – Palestine (DCIP), U.S. lawmakers, and advocacy figures, who argue that Israel is the only country that systematically prosecutes children in military courts. Despite being a U.S. citizen, he remains in detention, and his family and U.S. officials are urging the Trump administration to use diplomatic pressure to secure his release. The case has gained renewed urgency following the Gaza ceasefire deal and the release of other Palestinian detainees, as well as reports of abuse and deaths of Palestinian prisoners since October 2023.
title: Cold cells, meagre meals: Palestinian American boy suffers in Israeli jail
